# Metodología

## Diseño

Este es un estudio cuantitativo de diseño transversal, centrado en los resultados del proceso de admisión a la educación superior selectiva del año 2022. Además del análisis descriptivo de los factores académicos de admisión (NEM, Ranking, y pruebas de admisión en matemáticas y lenguaje), se estimó un modelo de senderos, o path analysis, para analizar el efecto que variables socioeconómicas de interés (estudiante primera generación y quintil de ingresos percápita por familia) sobre distintos resultados de admisión.

## Datos

Los datos corresponden al proceso de admisión del año 2022, los cuales fueron solicitados al DEMRE. A diferencia de procesos anteriores, el DEMRE ahora facilita un único repositorio con la información de las distintas etapas del proceso.

Entre las variables extraídas de la fuente original se encuentran los puntajes en las pruebas de admisión en lenguaje y matemáticas, puntajes derivados de las notas de enseñanza media (NEM y Ranking), educación del padre y la madre, decil de ingresos percápita por familia, y situación de las postulaciones del estudiante.

```{r, include=FALSE}
library(dplyr)

# Database
dat <- readr::read_delim("C:/Users/geral/OneDrive - University of Iowa/PhD portfolio/1.-Research/8. Multivariate analysis of admission progression/2. Database/ADM2022.csv", delim = ";", escape_double = FALSE, trim_ws = TRUE)

# Data cleaning

## Academic filters
dat1 <- dat %>% filter(P166  %in% c('310', '410', '510', '610','710','810','910') & # students who learned from the regular curriculum
                 P015 == 2021 & # students graduated in 2021
                 P083 > 0 & P084 > 0 & P085 > 0 & P086 > 0) # students with valid scores in the academic factors

# Sample
dat2 <- dat1[,c('P034_1', # per capita income
        'P037', # Dad's education
        'P038', # Mom's education
        'P098', # Regular application status
        'P083', # NEM
        'P084', # RKG
        'P085', # LANG
        'P086',# MATH
         'P100',
         'P105',
         'P110',
         'P115',
         'P120',
         'P125',
         'P130',
         'P135',
         'P140',
         'P145')] 

dat3 <- dat2 %>% mutate(
  P034_1 = ifelse(P034_1 == 99, NA, P034_1),
  Q_FAM_INC = recode(P034_1,
                     '1' = 1,'2' = 1,
                     '3' = 2,'4' = 2,
                     '5' = 3,'6' = 3,
                     '7' = 4,'8' = 4,
                     '9' = 5,'10' = 5),
  Q2 = ifelse(Q_FAM_INC == 2,1,0),
  Q3 = ifelse(Q_FAM_INC == 3,1,0),
  Q4 = ifelse(Q_FAM_INC == 4,1,0),
  Q5 = ifelse(Q_FAM_INC == 5,1,0),
  P037_1 = ifelse(P037 == 13 | P037 == 99, -1, P037), # father
  P038_1 = ifelse(P038 == 13 | P038 == 99, -1, P038), # mother
  FIRST_G = ifelse(P037_1 > 9 | P038_1 > 9, 0, 1),
  FIRST_G = ifelse(P037_1 == -1 & P038_1 == -1, NA, FIRST_G),
  ADM = ifelse(is.na(P098),0,
               ifelse(P098 == 'C', 1,4)),
  SEL = ifelse(ADM == 4 &
                 (P100 == 24 |
                 P105 == 24 |
                 P110 == 24 |
                 P115 == 24 |
                 P120 == 24 |
                 P125 == 24 |
                 P130 == 24 |
                 P135 == 24 |
                 P140 == 24 |
                 P145 == 24), 1,0),
  SEL2 = ifelse(ADM == 4 & SEL == 1, 1,
               ifelse(ADM == 4 & SEL == 0, 0, NA)),
  ADM2 = ifelse(ADM == 4 & SEL2 == 0,2,
                       ifelse(ADM == 4 & SEL2 == 1,3, ADM)))

# ADM 1 = did not apply;
# 2 = none of his/her applications met the minimum requirements;
# 3 = applied but was not selected;
# 4 = applied and was selected

dat4 <- data.frame(dat3[,c("P083","P084","P085","P086","Q2","Q3","Q4","Q5","FIRST_G","ADM2")])
colnames(dat4) <- c("NEM","RKG","LANG","MATH","Q2","Q3","Q4","Q5","FIRST_G","ADM")
dat4$ADM <- recode(dat4$ADM, '3' = 2, '2' = 3)
dat4 <- dat4 %>% mutate(
  NEM = (NEM - 550)/100,
  RKG = (RKG - 550)/100,
  LANG = (LANG - 550)/100,
  MATH = (MATH - 550)/100)
dat3_5 <- data.frame(dat3[,c(1:8,19:30)])
```

```{r}
head(dat3_5,10)
head(dat4,10)
```
Como pueden darse cuenta, solo dos variables se consideraron como predictores de interés. En el caso de las variables de caracterización de los colegios, no se agregaron por conveniencia, ya que al incluirlos necesitaríamos ajustar el modelo a la estructura anidada de los datos para identificar adecuamente el rol de cada predictor en distintos niveles (al interior y entre colegios) y no tener errores estándar sesgados en los efectos de nivel 1. Además, como la pregunta de investigación involucra aspectos sociodemográficos, no se agregaron variables demográficas.

## Muestra

Originalmente, existen 281.457 registros en la base de datos del proceso de admisión 2022 provista por el DEMRE. Sin embargo, de acuerdo con el objetivo de investigación, se aplicaron 3 filtros a la base de datos original:

1. Egresados/as de enseñanza regular (`n = 258.728`)
2. Graduados/as en 2021 (`n = 172.346`)
3. Puntajes válidos en los factores académicos de selección (`n = 150.811`)

Con esto, pretendemos fijar un perfil de estudiante: aquel estudiante recién egresado de la educación secundaria con cuyos contenidos se diseñan los exámenes de admisión y que tiene los puntajes necesarios para la construcción del puntaje ponderado que se utiliza para postular a cada programa universitario.

## Procedimiento

En primer lugar, se realizaron análisis descriptivos de los puntajes en los factores académicos de admisión según las variables de caracterización socioeconómicas escogidas.

Luego, se estimaron dos modelos de senderos en el software Mplus v.8.8, uno con las mediaciones de los factores académicos (estimando los tradicionales efectos `a`, `b` y `c'`), y otro sin estos efectos (las regresiones entre los mediadores y el resultado se fija en `@0`). Esto permitiría luego comparar los efectos c (incondicionales) con los c' (condicionales), sin embargo, las formulas disponibles para hacer esto [ver ecuación 11.6 en @mackinnon2012introduction] consideran solo un mediador, mientras que en nuestro análisis tenemos 4. Por esto, los efectos indirectos se presentan con la clásica opción de a*b (efectos no estandarizados).

**Logica del modelo**

![Note.](https://github.com/Bladimir-PF/PresentacionIESED2023/blob/main/4.%20Tablas%20y%20figuras/Table%201.png?raw=true)

El análisis de senderos es un modelo de regresión lineal múltiple (o logística multinomial) con esteroides. Es un conjunto de regresiones simultáneas que permite revisar si, en adición al efecto principal entre los predictores exógenos y la variable dependiente, existen efectos indirectos entre el predictor y el resultado que no pueden ser capturado por los modelos de regresión convencionales.

En nuestro caso, los predictores exógenos son las características socioeconómicas FIRST_G y FAMILY_INCOME, con los factores académicos actuando como mediadores. Los modelos se estimaron bajo Máxima Verosimilitud con errores estándar robustos (`MLR`), utilizando una distribución condicional `multinomial` para los residuos y función de enlace logit de referencia (`baseline logit`).

En síntesis, estamos tratando de estimar algo así:

![Tomado de MacKinnon (2008,p.303)](https://github.com/Bladimir-PF/PresentacionIESED2023/blob/main/4.%20Tablas%20y%20figuras/Figure%203.png?raw=true)

Con un modelo que calcula esto:

![Tomado de https://www.datasklr.com/logistic-regression/multinomial-logistic-regression](https://github.com/Bladimir-PF/PresentacionIESED2023/blob/main/4.%20Tablas%20y%20figuras/Multinomial%20logistic%20regression.png?raw=true)

Y que luce así:

![Hecho en SEMBuilder, STATA](https://github.com/Bladimir-PF/PresentacionIESED2023/blob/main/4.%20Tablas%20y%20figuras/Figure%202.png?raw=true)

```{r, include=FALSE}
library(ggplot2)

dat5 <- dat3[,c('P083','P084','P085','P086','Q_FAM_INC','P037_1','P038_1','FIRST_G','ADM2')]

str(dat5)
dat5 <- dat5 %>% mutate(
  FAMILY_INCOME = factor(FAMILY_INCOME),
  FIRST_G = factor(FIRST_G),
  ADM = factor(ADM),
  EDUCATION_FATHER = ifelse(EDUCATION_FATHER >= 1 & EDUCATION_FATHER <=5, 0,
                    ifelse(EDUCATION_FATHER >= 6 & EDUCATION_FATHER <= 9, 1,
                           ifelse(EDUCATION_FATHER == -1, NA, 2))),
  EDUCATION_MOTHER = ifelse(EDUCATION_MOTHER >= 1 & EDUCATION_MOTHER <=5, 0,
                    ifelse(EDUCATION_MOTHER >= 6 & EDUCATION_MOTHER <= 9, 1,
                           ifelse(EDUCATION_MOTHER == -1, NA, 2))),
  
  EDUCATION_FATHER = factor(EDUCATION_FATHER),
  EDUCATION_MOTHER = factor(EDUCATION_MOTHER))
summary(dat5)
```

# Working Directory
The working directory is the $directory$ or $path$ or $folder$ in which you are working. Every R instance has its own work directory as default. So, when you are trying to read data in R, you need to be sure that the object with the data that you are calling is in the location that you are working on or you are calling it from is the proper location. The function `getwd()` will display the name of the current working directory and the function `setwd()` will allow you to change the current directory to the desired one, of course to change the directory, you will need to enter the proper path to the desired directory. The path will change depending on the operating system that you may be using (e.g., linux, mac, windows) and the location of the directory. Let's see an example

```{r, eval=FALSE}

# everything that comes after a # symbol is a comment and not process
# to check the current directory
getwd()
# to set a new working directory to the folder label 'Documents'
# assume that the username is 'ariel'
# linux
setwd('/home/ariel/Documents/')
# mac
setwd('/Volumes/ariel/Documents/')
# windows
setwd('C:/ariel/Documents/')
```

# Functions and Arguments
Functions are programmed to execute different tasks. For example, `getwd()` is a function that allows to display the path to the current working directory. The more complex the function, the more arguments that the function may include. Arguments in functions can take the form of objects, names, or options. All functions in `R` provided by the base install or by packages have some source of documentation, explaining the inputs, process, and the outputs of those functions. 

# Linear Models
One of the most common functions to execute linear models in `R` is the `lm()` function. This function, includes several different arguments. The basic structure of the `lm()` function is 

<div align="center">`lm(outcome ~ X1 + X2, data = mydata)` </div>
where `lm` stands for the function to perform a linear model, `outcome` will be replaced by the name of the outcome in the data set, the `~` symbol takes the place of the equal in the formula, so we will keep it always there when using the `lm()` function, `X1 + X2` represents the names of two possible predictors of covariates (the intercept is already in the formula as default so we do not need to explicitly add it), and `data = ` is the argument where we define our data set, so the `mydat` will be replaced with the name of the object that stores the data set.

## Minimal Example

Below we have the code for an example using the `cars` data set which is one of the many data sets available in base `R`.

```{r }
# we make the data avaiable first
data("cars")
```

Let's see the first six observations for each variable in this data set by using the function `head()` as we can see in the code
```{r }
head(cars)
```

Now, we will fit a linear model, but we will store the output information of our model in our object name `fit1`, you can use any name and sometimes its useful to pick a more descriptive name. Then, when we replace the word `outcome` for the name of the variable that we used as outcome in our data set, which is the variable `speed`, and we have only one predictor or covariate in the data set, so our predictor is `dist`, also notice that our predictor is in the right side of the `~` symbol. Finally, we declare the name of our data set after the `data = `, in this case, we replace the `mydat` above for `cars`.
```{r }
fit1 <- lm(speed ~ dist, data = cars)
```

At this point all the information about our data and model are stored in the `fit1` object. To access to this information we use the `summary()` function as seen below. 

```{r }
summary(fit1)
```

# Working With the Server
All the `R` code that you need for class, is located in our server. To complete your assignments, you will need to upload your data to the server using the upload button in `Rstudio` keep in mind that you will need to know the exact location and path to where you are saving your data to be able to make the data available in the working memory. 

At the end of the semester, you should also download your whole folder to save your work, plus the code that I have provided. 

# Recomended Workflow for This Class
I suggest that:

- you get use to using `Rstudio` using the university server. You will need to log in using the link provided in class and the two-factor authentication. Once you are in the server, you can open scripts to type your `R` code, scripts have the extension `.R`; of course you can also prefer to use `.Rmd` or `.Rnw` if you are intending to embed text, code, and output or some combination of those. 

- you create your own folder within the server and copy the original files that I provide for class there. The idea is that in this way, you can make notes and modify those files as needed. Also, when you create your own scripts, you should save them in your folder so you can always go back to them and reproduce what you have done. 

- you watch the videos, read the handouts, and other materials prior to each class. During most classes, we will work on activities and exercises based on the materials that you watched and read. It is your responsibility to come prepared to class. 

- also when you do the readings and watch the videos, please write down your questions. Then, you can send me your questions in an email prior to class and/or you can also directly ask those questions in class. The more that students ask questions the more interesting our classes will get! 

All the code that you will need will be provided to you, all you will need to know about the code, is how to change the variable names, the data file name, and of course, to be able to select the proper code to use for the proper analyses. 

Remember that learning statistics and `R` is similar to learning another language, it is easier for some people than others. But there are no secrets to how to do it; the bottom line is that the more you practice, the more natural that it will become. And the longer that you do it the better that you will get to it.
